questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to a mass noticed in his right groin. An ultrasound confirms that it is an undescended testis, located just at the superficial inguinal ring Based on the normal developmental timeline of testicular descent, at which intrauterine period should the testis have normally reached the deep inguinal ring?

options.label: A
options.text: 8th week of gestation

options.label: B
options.text: 3rd month of gestation

options.label: C
options.text: 5th month of gestation

options.label: D
options.text: 7th month of gestation

questions.text: Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding the peritoneal cavity?

options.label: A
options.text: The abdominal cavity is divided into supracolic and infracolic compartments.

options.label: B
options.text: The supracolic compartment is further divided into subphrenic spaces.

options.label: C
options.text: The infracolic compartment is divided into right and left parts by the falciform ligament.

options.label: D
options.text: The right paracolic gutter lies along the lateral side of the ascending colon.

questions.correct_answer: C. The infracolic compartment is divided into right and left parts by the falciform ligament.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with a mass in the right groin that is suspected to be an ovary. Imaging confirms that her ovary has been drawn into the inguinal canal. Which structure is most likely responsible for the abnormal descent of the ovary into the inguinal canal?

options.label: A
options.text: Round ligament of the uterus

options.label: B
options.text: Suspensory ligament of the ovary

options.label: C
options.text: Broad ligament of the uterus

options.label: D
options.text: Uterosacral ligament

questions.correct_answer: A. Round ligament of the uterus

questions.text: Which of the following structures is NOT found in the spermatic cord?

options.label: A
options.text: Vas deferens

options.label: B
options.text: Testicular artery

options.label: C
options.text: Epididymis

options.label: D
options.text: Pampiniform plexus

questions.text: What is the correct order of the layers of the anterior abdominal wall from superficial to deep?

options.label: A
options.text: Skin → Scarpa fascia → Internal oblique → External oblique → Transversalis fascia → Transversus abdominis → Peritoneum

options.label: B
options.text: Skin → Transversalis fascia → Internal oblique → External oblique → Transversus abdominis → Scarpa fascia → Peritoneum

options.label: C
options.text: Skin → Scarpa fascia → External oblique → Internal oblique → Transversus abdominis → Transversalis fascia → Peritoneum

options.label: D
options.text: Skin → External oblique → Scarpa fascia → Internal oblique → Transversus abdominis → Transversalis fascia → Peritoneum

questions.correct_answer: C. Skin → Scarpa fascia → External oblique → Internal oblique → Transversus abdominis → Transversalis fascia → Peritoneum
questions.explanation: Correct Answer:C) Skin → Scarpa fascia → External oblique → Internal oblique → Transversus abdominis → Transversalis fascia → Peritoneu

questions.text: At which level does the rectus sheath become entirely posterior to the rectus abdominis muscle?

options.label: A
options.text: At the level of the xiphoid process

options.label: B
options.text: At the level of umbilicus

options.label: C
options.text: At the arcuate line

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the inguinal canal is false?

options.label: A
options.text: The posterior wall of the inguinal canal is formed by the transversalis fascia.

options.label: B
options.text: The inguinal canal contains the ilioinguinal nerve.

options.label: C
options.text: The aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle forms the roof of the inguinal canal.

options.label: D
options.text: In males, the inguinal canal contains the spermatic cord.

questions.correct_answer: C. The aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle forms the roof of the inguinal canal.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer:C) The aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle forms the roof of the inguinal canal.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a swelling in the right inguinal region that increases in size on coughing or standing. Upon examination, a diagnosis of indirect inguinal hernia is made, and surgical repair is planned. While preparing for the surgery, the anatomical relations of the inguinal canal are reviewed. Which of the following correctly describes the anatomical relations of the inguinal canal?

options.label: A
options.text: The posterior wall of the inguinal canal is formed by the transversalis fascia.

options.label: B
options.text: The inguinal canal contains the inferior epigastric vessels.

options.label: C
options.text: The deep inguinal ring is located medial to the inferior epigastric vessels.

options.label: D
options.text: D) The floor of the inguinal canal is formed by the conjoint tendon

questions.correct_answer: A. The posterior wall of the inguinal canal is formed by the transversalis fascia.
questions.explanation:
Structure

Description

Parietal peritoneum

Most posterior structure.

Transversalis fascia

Has a defect called the deep inguinal ring, through which the testes and spermatic cord pass. Site for indirect inguinal hernias. Anterior to parietal peritoneum. Forms the posterior in the whole extent. (Option A)

Lateral umbilical fold

Formed by the inferior epigastric vessels.

Median umbilical ligament

Remnant of the urachus (from the allantois).

Medial umbilical ligament

Remnant of the obliterated umbilical artery.

Pyramidalis muscle

Small muscle attaching to the pubic bone. Rectus abdominis lies above it. Covered by the rectus sheath and supplied by the subcostal nerve (T12).

Rectus abdominis muscle

Receives segmental innervation from T6–T12.

Transversus abdominis muscle

Does not form the anterior wall of the inguinal canal. Contributes to the roof and posterior wall. Combines with internal oblique to form the conjoint tendon.

Internal oblique muscle

Forms parts of the anterior, roof, and posterior walls of the inguinal canal. Contributes to cremasteric muscle and fascia.

External oblique muscle

Aponeurosis forms the anterior wall of the inguinal canal and the superficial inguinal ring. Forms external spermatic fascia.

Internal spermatic fascia

Derived from the transversalis fascia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the femoral triangle is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: The medial boundary of the femoral triangle is formed by the adductor longus muscle.

options.label: B
options.text: The lateral boundary of the femoral triangle is formed by the iliacus and psoas major muscles

options.label: C
options.text: The femoral nerve is one of the contents of the femoral triangle.

options.label: D
options.text: The anterior boundary of the femoral ring is the inguinal ligament.

questions.correct_answer: B. The lateral boundary of the femoral triangle is formed by the iliacus and psoas major muscles
questions.explanation:
Femoral Triangle

Boundaries

Contents
  • Lateral Boundary: Medial margin of the sartorius muscle.
  • Medial Boundary: Medial margin of the adductor longus muscle.
  • Apex: The point where the sartorius overlaps the adductor longus.
  • Floor:
    • Laterally: Iliacus and psoas major muscles.
    • Medially: Pectineus and adductor longus muscles.
  • Roof: Formed by the overlying fascia lata.

The structures are arranged from medial to lateral in the following order (VAN):

  • Femoral vein (most medial) and Its Tributaries
  • Femoral artery and Its Branches
  • Femoral nerve (most lateral)
 
  • Femoral Sheath
  • Nerves:
    • Femoral Nerve
    • Nerve to Pectineus
    • Femoral Branch of Genitofemoral Nerve
    • Lateral Cutaneous Nerve of the Thigh
  • Deep Inguinal Lymph Nodes

Femoral Ring- Base (upper end) of Femoral Canal

Boundaries

Contents
  1. Anterior: Inguinal ligament
  2. Posterior: Pectineus and its covering fascia
  3. Medial: Concave margin of lacunar ligament
  4. Lateral: Femoral vein
  1. Lymph node of Cloquet (Rosenmüller)
  2. Lymphatics
  3. Areolar tissue

questions.text: Which of the marked structures is formed directly by the rotation of the stomach and duodenum?

options.label: A
options.text: both a and b

options.label: B
options.text: both b and c

options.label: C
options.text: b only

options.label: D
options.text: d only

questions.text: A 50-year-old male undergoes an emergency laparotomy for severe upper abdominal bleeding after blunt abdominal trauma. During the procedure, the surgeon performs the Pringle maneuver by clamping the hepatoduodenal ligament to control hemorrhage. The clamp is applied to temporarily occlude the portal triad and assess the source of bleeding. Which structure forms the superior boundary of the anatomical space where the Pringle maneuver is performed?

options.label: A
options.text: Inferior vena cava

options.label: B
options.text: Caudate lobe of the liver

options.label: C
options.text: First part of the duodenum

options.label: D
options.text: Proper hepatic artery

questions.correct_answer: B. Caudate lobe of the liver

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with lower abdominal pain, high fever, and an elevated heart rate. She appears pale and diaphoretic on examination, with hypotension and a leukocytosis noted on laboratory tests. Imaging reveals a pelvic abscess. The surgeon suspects that pus has spread from an upper abdominal source. Which of the following sequences represents the correct flow of pus between important peritoneal spaces, leading to a pelvic abscess?

options.label: A
options.text: Rectouterine pouch → Hepatorenal pouch → Paracolic gutter → Lesser sac → Pelvic abscess

options.label: B
options.text: Lesser sac → Foramen of Winslow → Greater sac → Hepatorenal pouch → Paracolic gutter → Rectouterine pouch → Pelvic abscess

options.label: C
options.text: Greater sac → Foramen of Winslow → Hepatorenal pouch → Paracolic gutter → Lesser sac → Pelvic abscess

options.label: D
options.text: Hepatorenal pouch → Paracolic gutter → Lesser sac → Foramen of Winslow → Pelvic abscess

questions.correct_answer: B. Lesser sac → Foramen of Winslow → Greater sac → Hepatorenal pouch → Paracolic gutter → Rectouterine pouch → Pelvic abscess

questions.text: Which muscle is primarily involved in a midline abdominal incision?

options.label: A
options.text: Rectus Abdominis

options.label: B
options.text: External Oblique

options.label: C
options.text: Internal Oblique

options.label: D
options.text: Transverse Abdominis

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the conjoint tendon is false ?

options.label: A
options.text: The conjoint tendon is formed by the fusion of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles.

options.label: B
options.text: The conjoint tendon contributes to the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

options.label: C
options.text: The conjoint tendon is located in the anterior wall of the inguinal canal.

options.label: D
options.text: A weakness in the conjoint tendon can lead to a direct inguinal hernia.

questions.correct_answer: C. The conjoint tendon is located in the anterior wall of the inguinal canal.
